name: steam production, as energy carrier, in chemical industry | heat, from steam, in chemical industry | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8185/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 MJ of steam used for heating in the chemical and petrochemical industry. It is to be used for heat energy production in an average chemical plant,  in case no information is available about the source of the heat energy. The inventory represents the average fuel mix used for steam production in the chemical and petrochemical industry.;The total energy required for the production of 1 MJ of steam is 1.31 MJ and is based on a study on steam production in the European chemical industry (Boustead 1999). The shares of the fuel mix used for heating are based on expert judgment for the situation in 2017. The water consumption is based on data collected from 11 chemical plants in Europe (Zah & Hischier 2007).;The energy content of the steam is 2.75 MJ/kg. The overall efficiency is 74% when taking into account the input of recovered energy (0.047 MJ per MJ of steam).;References:;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.;Boustead I. (1999) Ecoprofiles of plastics and related intermediates, Steam (on-site average). European Centre for Plastics in the Environment (APME), Brussels.;Zah R., Hischier R. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Detergents. ecoinvent report No.;12. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.

The activity starts with the input of heat, electricity and water.

The activity ends with the production of 1 MJ heat (=0.3636 kg) steam from cold water. The activity includes water losses, but does not include the use of additives.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Based on world energy consumption in the chemical and petrochemical industry.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average technology used in the chemical and petrochemical industry.;Two types of boilers are commonly used:;;1) fired tube boilers, which are cylinder-shaped, and closed at both ends by tubular plates enclosing the following items: a large diameter furnace tube passing longitudinally through the cylindrical body, and in which combustion occurs; flue gas tubes (or smoke tubes) in which the flue gas circulate.;Schematic view of a fire tube boiler:;These boilers produce steam and high pressure hot water, and their power ranges from 3 to 20 MWt. They are currently most often equipped with low NOx type burners, which use primary measures for the reduction of NOx emissions (natural gas staging technique or/and flue gas recirculation). ;2) water tube boiler, which comprises many tubes connected to 1 or 2 tanks; the upper tank containing the water-steam emulsion, and the lower tank containing water.;Schematic view of a water tube boiler:;Most often this type of boiler is built specifically according to the power and specifications required. The range of powers starts at 15 or 20 MWt, up to several hundreds of MWth, and even beyond. They are currently most often equipped with low NOx type burners, that use natural gas staging technique or/and internal flue gas recirculation.;Reference:;Zah R., Hischier R. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Detergents. ecoinvent report No.;12. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
The data is based on literature and statistics.
The fuel consumption mix used for the production of heat is estimated based on expert judgement. The total energy (1.31 MJ) and electricity required for the production of 1 MJ of heat in the form of steam is based on the dataset covering the geography RER.
The water consumption is based on data on steam production from 11 European plants that produce sodium silicates or percarbonate (Zah & Hischier 2007).

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Zah R., Hischier R. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Detergents. ecoinvent report No. 12. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.

exchanges.description: Energy content of steam = 2.75 MJ/kg or 2.4 MJ/kg (latter if condensed steam is reheated).

flow.name: heat, from steam, in chemical industry
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

exchanges.description:
Literature value, based on the study by Boustead (1999) regarding the European chemical sector. 

The total energy required for producing 1 MJ of steam is 1.31 MJ (total energy mix) (Boustead, 1999), corresponding to an overall efficiency of 74% (when taking into account the input of 0.047 MJ of recovered energy). In the same source,  the value of 0.00808 KWh electricity input for producing 1.31 MJ is given. These values are used as an estimation in the present global inventory, due to lack of more accurate data. 

1 KWh is equal to 3.6MJ.

exchanges.description: Value based on data from 11 chemical plants in Europe. 1.17 kg of tap water is required for the production of 1 kg of steam, therefore 0.17 kg of water is lost per kg of steam produced, while the rest is recirculated. Based on the energy content of steam of 2.75 MJ/kg, 0.062 kg of water is lost per MJ of steam produced.

exchanges.description:
Estimated value based on literature.

Calculated from the energy consumption mix for the chemical and petrochemical industry based on expert judgement. The fraction of natural gas corresponds to 0.5. The fraction of fuel oil is 0.3. The fraction of inputs of coal & peat is 0.2.

The total energy required for producing 1 MJ of steam is 1.31 MJ (total energy mix) (Boustead, 1999), corresponding to an overall efficiency of 74% (when taking into account the input of 0.047 MJ of recovered energy). This study is based on the European chemical sector. In the same source, the value of 0.00808 KWh electricity input for producing 1.31 MJ is given. These values are used as an estimation in the present global inventory, due to lack of more accurate data. 

1 KWh is equal to 3.6 MJ.
